arch:property.oc:show_val: L4000 was formerly part of L4021 (Level 8) when the trench was a section called F4. The locus was started because we found a complete pot (SF KT#4027) on a mound of hard burnt clay, apparently in situ in undisturbed context. There was some loose fine grained slit still in the pot so we took a sample (KT 4028). The rest of the surface is far from level and is made of very hard clay/mudbrick like material. We closed the locus when we found a large collection of what looked like surface material, bones, pottery and a few small finds found flat on the floor
light gray with burnt clay and ash spots
very compacted spots like mudbrick with looser dirt surrounding
ash/burnt clay, pebbles, small pot sherds

an almost complete pot was found atop some burnt clay and ash. No pit or surface was found but the strata indicates that we are under a surface. The present layer must have been closed by a layer of tightly compacted clayey silt.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area F / Trench 4 / Locus 4000 (Locus)
